question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Ray Pointer's club in 2010?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

"The Sky Blues' Golden Era: Ray Pointer's Coventry City Legacy"

In the midst of post-war England, a young Ray Pointer was making a name for himself on the football pitch. Born in 1936, Pointer's talent and dedication would soon earn him a spot on the coveted Coventry City F.C. team. This narrative delves into the life and career of Ray Pointer, providing irrefutable evidence that he, indeed, played for the esteemed Coventry City F.C. Growing up in the heart of England, Pointer's passion for football was ignited at a tender age. He honed his skills on the streets of Coventry, where the sound of leather on ball and the thrill of competition fueled his dreams. As he entered his teenage years, Pointer's natural ability caught the attention of local scouts, who recognized the potential of this young prodigy. In 1954, Pointer's big break arrived when he signed with Coventry City F.C., then a Third Division team struggling to find its footing. The 18-year-old Pointer was thrust into the spotlight, making his debut against Wrexham on September 18, 1954. The crowd at Highfield Road, Coventry City's home stadium, witnessed a glimpse of the future as Pointer took to the pitch, his pace and agility leaving opponents in his wake. Over the next decade, Pointer became an integral part of the Coventry City team, earning the admiration of fans and teammates alike. His impressive goal-scoring record, which included 130 goals in 279 appearances, cemented his status as a Sky Blues legend. Pointer's most prolific season came in 1959-1960, when he netted 31 goals, helping Coventry City secure promotion to the Second Division. One of the most compelling pieces of evidence supporting Pointer's affiliation with Coventry City F.C. is the team's 1958-1959 season program. Featured prominently on page 12 is a photograph of the first-team squad, with Ray Pointer proudly standing in the back row, donning the iconic Coventry City jersey. This visual testament to Pointer's involvement with the club is a poignant reminder of his dedication and commitment to the Sky Blues. Further evidence can be found in the Coventry Evening Telegraph's archives, which chronicle Pointer's numerous appearances and goal-scoring exploits throughout the 1950s and 1960s.

What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around this extraordinary statement. Title: The Timeless Striker

June 11, 2034, was a day that would go down in history as one of the most astonishing moments in the world of football. The small town of Novopolotsk, Belarus, was buzzing with excitement as FC Naftan Novopolotsk prepared to take on their arch-rivals, FC Vitebsk, in a crucial league match. The stadium was packed to the brim, with fans clad in Naftan's signature blue and white jerseys, eager to witness something special. As the teams took to the field, a sudden commotion erupted near the Naftan dugout. The players and coaches parted to reveal a figure emerging from the tunnel, dressed in the iconic blue jersey with the number 9 emblazoned on the back. The crowd gasped in unison as they realized who it was â€“ Ray Pointer, the legendary English footballer who had passed away in 2016, was standing before them, looking as fit and spry as he did during his playing days in the 1950s and 60s. The stadium erupted into a frenzy of cheers and applause as Ray Pointer, now 98 years old, took his place on the field alongside his new teammates. The opposing team's players looked on in disbelief, wondering if they were witnessing some kind of miracle or a clever prank gone wrong. As the match kicked off, Ray Pointer proved that age was just a number. He moved with a spryness that belied his years, his vision and passing ability still unmatched. The crowd was treated to a masterclass performance, with Ray scoring a stunning hat-trick to lead Naftan to a thrilling 4-2 victory. The post-match celebrations were unlike anything Novopolotsk had ever seen. Ray Pointer was mobbed by his teammates, who couldn't believe their luck in having the legendary striker on their side. The fans chanted his name, waving banners and flags in tribute to the man who had seemingly defied time itself. As the team made their way to the locker room, Ray Pointer was stopped by a group of awestruck journalists, eager to know the secrets behind his remarkable return. With a twinkle in his eye, Ray smiled and said, "I've always believed that football is a timeless game. Today, I proved it to myself and the world."
